note_text:
Interventional Pulmonology Procedure Note
Procedure: Medical thoracoscopy with talc pleurodesis for malignant pleural effusion.
Patient: Daniel Carter, 68-year-old male with metastatic lung adenocarcinoma and recurrent left pleural effusion.
Anesthesia: General anesthesia with double-lumen endotracheal tube.
Indication: Symptomatic, rapidly recurrent left malignant pleural effusion after multiple prior therapeutic thoracenteses.
Procedure details: Under ultrasound guidance, the left 6th intercostal space in the midaxillary line was selected. Approximately 1.8 L of serosanguinous pleural fluid was drained through a trocar. A semi-rigid thoracoscope was introduced. Diffuse parietal pleural studding and nodularity were seen, with trapped lung but near-complete re-expansion after drainage. Multiple parietal pleural biopsies were obtained. A talc slurry (4 g in 50 mL normal saline) was distributed evenly over the parietal pleura while rotating the patient. A 24 Fr chest tube was left in place and connected to −20 cmH2O suction.
Complications: None; transient hypotension responsive to fluids.
Estimated blood loss: 25 mL.
Disposition: Admitted to floor with chest tube to suction.
Plan: Daily chest radiographs, monitor drainage; remove chest tube when output <150 mL/day and lung fully expanded; oncology follow-up once pathology finalized.

registry_entry.primary_indication: Recurrent symptomatic left malignant pleural effusion from lung adenocarcinoma
registry_entry.radiographic_findings: Large left pleural effusion with compressive atelectasis of the left lower lobe
registry_entry.prior_therapy: Three prior therapeutic thoracenteses in the past 6 weeks
registry_entry.pleural_thoracoscopy_findings: Diffuse parietal pleural nodularity and studding consistent with malignant pleural involvement
registry_entry.bronch_specimen_tests: Pleural biopsies for histology and immunohistochemistry
registry_entry.final_diagnosis_prelim: Suspected malignant pleural effusion; pleural biopsies pending
registry_entry.follow_up_plan: Daily CXRs; remove chest tube once drainage low and lung expanded; oncology clinic within 1–2 weeks

note_text:
Interventional Pulmonology Procedure Note
Procedure: Medical thoracoscopy with mechanical pleurodesis for mesothelioma.
Patient: Maria Lopez, 73-year-old female with biopsy-proven epithelioid malignant pleural mesothelioma and recurrent right effusion.
Anesthesia: General anesthesia with single-lumen ETT and bronchial blocker.
Indication: Progressive dyspnea from large recurrent right malignant pleural effusion despite prior thoracenteses.
Procedure details: Right lateral decubitus positioning. The 5th intercostal space at the midaxillary line was opened with a 2 cm incision. Entry into the pleural space resulted in immediate drainage of 1.2 L of serous fluid. A rigid thoracoscope was used to inspect the pleural cavity, revealing circumferential parietal pleural thickening and tumor implants. Mechanical pleurodesis was performed using a gauze pad and thoracoscopic scratcher across the parietal pleura, followed by instillation of 500 mg doxycycline in 50 mL saline as adjunct sclerosing agent. A 28 Fr chest tube was secured in the posterior axillary line.
Complications: Mild oozing from pleural surfaces controlled with cautery; no hemodynamic instability.
Estimated blood loss: 40 mL.
Disposition: Admitted to thoracic surgery floor with chest tube to suction.
Plan: Maintain suction at −20 cmH2O; remove chest tube when drainage <150 mL/day and CXR stable; oncology follow-up for systemic therapy.

registry_entry.radiographic_findings: Large right pleural effusion with circumferential pleural thickening
registry_entry.prior_therapy: Systemic pemetrexed/platinum; serial therapeutic thoracenteses
registry_entry.pleural_thoracoscopy_findings: Diffuse parietal pleural thickening and tumor implants consistent with mesothelioma
registry_entry.bronch_specimen_tests: Additional pleural biopsies submitted for histology and biomarkers
registry_entry.final_diagnosis_prelim: Known malignant pleural mesothelioma with successful pleurodesis
registry_entry.follow_up_plan: Daily drainage monitoring; early ambulation and incentive spirometry; oncology clinic in 2 weeks

note_text:
Interventional Pulmonology Procedure Note
Procedure: Medical thoracoscopy with talc pleurodesis for recurrent breast cancer–related malignant pleural effusion.
Patient: Hannah Nguyen, 61-year-old female with metastatic ER+/HER2− breast carcinoma and symptomatic right pleural effusion.
Anesthesia: Monitored anesthesia care with propofol infusion and supplemental oxygen via face mask.
Indication: Dyspnea on exertion and orthopnea from recurrent right pleural effusion despite three thoracenteses.
Procedure details: After ultrasound localization, the right 7th intercostal space in the posterior axillary line was infiltrated with lidocaine and bupivacaine. A single-port semi-rigid medical thoracoscope was introduced after trocar insertion. Approximately 1.4 L of serous fluid was drained. The parietal pleura showed patchy nodularity over the diaphragmatic and posterior pleura. Biopsies were obtained from representative nodules. A talc slurry (4 g in 100 mL saline) was instilled and distributed with patient rotation. A 20 Fr chest tube was secured.
Complications: None.
Estimated blood loss: 15 mL.
Disposition: Admitted overnight for monitoring and chest tube management.
Plan: Transition chest tube to water seal once air leak resolves; remove when drainage <150 mL/day; resume systemic therapy per oncology.

registry_entry.radiographic_findings: Moderate to large right pleural effusion with right lower lobe compressive atelectasis

registry_entry.pleural_thoracoscopy_findings: Patchy diaphragmatic and posterior pleural nodularity consistent with metastatic disease
registry_entry.bronch_specimen_tests: Pleural biopsies for histology and receptor status confirmation as needed
registry_entry.final_diagnosis_prelim: Recurrent malignant pleural effusion with successful talc pleurodesis
registry_entry.follow_up_plan: Daily CXR until lung expansion stable; chest tube removal once drainage low; oncology follow-up within 1–2 weeks

note_text:
Interventional Pulmonology Procedure Note
Procedure: Medical thoracoscopy with talc pleurodesis for hepatic hydrothorax.
Patient: Samuel Ortiz, 59-year-old male with decompensated cirrhosis and refractory right hepatic hydrothorax.
Anesthesia: General anesthesia with single-lumen ETT.
Indication: Dyspnea and frequent hospitalizations for large right transudative pleural effusion despite sodium restriction and diuretics.
Procedure details: Ultrasound localization identified a large free-flowing right effusion. A 2 cm incision was made in the right 6th intercostal space, midaxillary line. After trocar insertion, 2.1 L of clear, straw-colored fluid was drained. Thoracoscopic inspection showed smooth parietal pleura without nodularity. No suspicious lesions were biopsied. Mechanical abrasion pleurodesis was performed using a thoracoscopic pad; 4 g of sterile talc in 100 mL saline was then distributed evenly. A 24 Fr chest tube was placed posteriorly.
Complications: Transient hypotension corrected with albumin bolus; no bleeding.
Estimated blood loss: 10 mL.
Disposition: Admitted to step-down unit for close monitoring of hemodynamics and chest tube output.
Plan: Albumin replacement for large volume drainage; chest tube to suction initially, then water seal; hepatology consultation regarding TIPS.

registry_entry.primary_indication: Refractory right hepatic hydrothorax with dyspnea
registry_entry.radiographic_findings: Massive right pleural effusion with near-complete right lower lobe collapse; cirrhotic liver morphology on prior imaging
registry_entry.prior_therapy: Maximal diuretics and multiple therapeutic thoracenteses
registry_entry.pleural_thoracoscopy_findings: Smooth, glistening pleura without nodularity or plaque
registry_entry.final_diagnosis_prelim: Refractory hepatic hydrothorax treated with thoracoscopic talc pleurodesis
registry_entry.follow_up_plan: Monitor daily weights and chest tube output; hepatology to evaluate for TIPS; outpatient follow-up within 4 weeks

note_text:
Interventional Pulmonology Procedure Note
Procedure: Medical thoracoscopy with talc pleurodesis for recurrent spontaneous pneumothorax.
Patient: Liam Johnson, 27-year-old male with recurrent primary left spontaneous pneumothorax.
Anesthesia: General anesthesia with left lung isolation using a double-lumen ETT.
Indication: Third episode of left spontaneous pneumothorax with persistent air leak after chest tube drainage.
Procedure details: The patient was positioned in right lateral decubitus. Entry into the left pleural space at the 5th intercostal space yielded a small amount of serosanguinous fluid and air. Thoracoscopic inspection revealed several apical blebs and normal visceral pleura elsewhere. The apical blebs were stapled with an endoscopic stapler by the thoracic surgery team (documented separately). Medical thoracoscopy team performed mechanical pleurodesis along the apical and parietal pleura using gauze pads, followed by insufflation of 4 g sterile talc as dry powder. A 24 Fr chest tube was left at the apex.
Complications: Brief intraoperative desaturation to 88% during lung isolation, resolved with recruitment maneuvers.
Estimated blood loss: 20 mL.
Disposition: Admitted to floor with chest tube to suction.
Plan: Daily CXRs; chest tube removal when no air leak and lung fully expanded on water seal; smoking cessation counseling.

registry_entry.institution_name: Synthetic Thoracic Surgery and IP Center
registry_entry.primary_indication: Recurrent left primary spontaneous pneumothorax with persistent air leak
registry_entry.radiographic_findings: Moderate left apical pneumothorax with chest tube in situ; CT with apical blebs
registry_entry.prior_therapy: Two prior hospitalizations with chest tube drainage alone
registry_entry.pleural_thoracoscopy_findings: Apical blebs and otherwise healthy pleura; no diffuse disease
registry_entry.final_diagnosis_prelim: Recurrent primary left spontaneous pneumothorax treated with thoracoscopic pleurodesis
registry_entry.follow_up_plan: Clinic visit in 2–4 weeks; reinforce smoking cessation; advise against high-altitude travel until cleared

note_text:
Interventional Pulmonology Procedure Note
Procedure: Medical thoracoscopy with talc pleurodesis for loculated malignant pleural effusion.
Patient: Olivia Brown, 65-year-old female with metastatic ovarian carcinoma and loculated left pleural effusion.
Anesthesia: Moderate sedation with midazolam and fentanyl; supplemental oxygen via nasal cannula.
Indication: Progressive dyspnea from loculated malignant pleural effusion not adequately drained by prior thoracentesis.
Procedure details: Bedside ultrasound showed multiple septations and loculations along the lateral left chest. A 2 cm incision was made at the 6th intercostal space, midaxillary line. Trocar insertion yielded 900 mL of serous fluid from the largest locule. A semi-rigid thoracoscope was advanced; adhesions were bluntly lysed to break down septations. Multiple parietal pleural biopsies were taken from nodular areas. After near-complete drainage, 4 g talc in 50 mL saline was instilled and distributed under direct visualization. A 20 Fr chest tube was placed and secured.
Complications: Mild pleuritic pain controlled with IV opioids; no hypotension or hypoxia.
Estimated blood loss: 30 mL.
Disposition: Admitted to oncology floor with chest tube to suction.
Plan: Transition to water seal on postoperative day 1; remove tube when drainage low; continue systemic chemotherapy per oncology.

registry_entry.primary_indication: Loculated left malignant pleural effusion causing dyspnea
registry_entry.radiographic_findings: Loculated left pleural effusion with multiple septations on ultrasound and CT
registry_entry.prior_therapy: Prior thoracentesis with incomplete drainage; ongoing systemic chemotherapy
registry_entry.pleural_thoracoscopy_findings: Multiple adhesions and nodular pleural implants consistent with metastatic disease
registry_entry.bronch_specimen_tests: Pleural biopsies for histology and cytology
registry_entry.final_diagnosis_prelim: Malignant pleural effusion with successful talc pleurodesis
registry_entry.follow_up_plan: Monitor chest tube output; remove when drainage low and lung expanded; follow up with oncology in 1–2 weeks

note_text:
Interventional Pulmonology Procedure Note
Procedure: Medical thoracoscopy with talc pleurodesis for malignant pleural effusion in non–small cell lung cancer.
Patient: Ethan Miller, 72-year-old male with stage IV squamous cell carcinoma and recurrent left pleural effusion.
Anesthesia: General anesthesia with single-lumen ETT.
Indication: Worsening dyspnea and orthopnea due to recurrent malignant pleural effusion despite prior chest tube drainage.
Procedure details: Left 6th intercostal space was selected under ultrasound guidance. Trocar entry produced a gush of serosanguinous fluid; 1.6 L was drained. Thoracoscopy showed nodular parietal and diaphragmatic pleura. Multiple biopsies were taken. After drainage, 4 g talc in 50 mL saline was instilled and spread evenly. A 24 Fr chest tube was secured.
Complications: None.
Estimated blood loss: 20 mL.
Disposition: Admitted to oncology floor with chest tube to suction.
Plan: Daily CXR and drainage monitoring; remove chest tube when output <150 mL/day; palliative care consult.

registry_entry.primary_indication: Recurrent left malignant pleural effusion from squamous cell lung carcinoma
registry_entry.radiographic_findings: Large left pleural effusion with mediastinal shift and compressive atelectasis
registry_entry.prior_therapy: Concurrent chemoradiation and prior chest tube drainage
registry_entry.pleural_thoracoscopy_findings: Diffusely nodular parietal and diaphragmatic pleura consistent with malignant involvement
registry_entry.bronch_specimen_tests: Pleural biopsies for histology and PD-L1 testing if needed
registry_entry.final_diagnosis_prelim: Malignant pleural effusion secondary to squamous cell lung carcinoma with successful talc pleurodesis
registry_entry.follow_up_plan: Palliative care and oncology follow-up; chest tube removal once drainage low and CXR stable

note_text:
Interventional Pulmonology Procedure Note
Procedure: Medical thoracoscopy with talc pleurodesis for malignant pleural effusion from renal cell carcinoma.
Patient: Noah Allen, 63-year-old male with metastatic clear cell renal carcinoma and left pleural effusion.
Anesthesia: Moderate sedation with midazolam and fentanyl; local anesthetic at port site.
Indication: Symptomatic recurrent left pleural effusion with prior positive cytology for renal cell carcinoma.
Procedure details: Ultrasound identified a large free-flowing effusion. A 2 cm incision at the 6th intercostal space allowed entry with a semi-rigid thoracoscope. 1.3 L of hemorrhagic fluid drained. Numerous hemorrhagic pleural implants were seen. Biopsies were obtained for confirmation. Talc slurry (4 g in 50 mL saline) was instilled with even distribution. A 20 Fr chest tube was secured.
Complications: None.
Estimated blood loss: 35 mL.
Disposition: Admitted overnight for chest tube management.
Plan: Daily CXR; remove chest tube once drainage low; outpatient oncology follow-up in 1 week.

registry_entry.primary_indication: Recurrent left malignant pleural effusion due to metastatic renal cell carcinoma
registry_entry.radiographic_findings: Moderate to large left pleural effusion; no large parenchymal masses
registry_entry.prior_therapy: Targeted systemic therapy; previous thoracentesis with positive cytology
registry_entry.pleural_thoracoscopy_findings: Diffuse hemorrhagic pleural implants consistent with metastatic renal cell carcinoma
registry_entry.final_diagnosis_prelim: Malignant pleural effusion secondary to metastatic renal cell carcinoma with successful pleurodesis
registry_entry.follow_up_plan: Oncology visit in 1 week; chest tube removal when drainage low and lung expanded

note_text:
Interventional Pulmonology Procedure Note
Procedure: Medical thoracoscopy with talc pleurodesis for malignant pleural effusion in mesothelioma (contralateral side).
Patient: James Cooper, 70-year-old male with biphasic malignant pleural mesothelioma and new left pleural effusion after prior right-sided pleurodesis.
Anesthesia: General anesthesia with single-lumen ETT.
Indication: Increasing dyspnea due to new contralateral effusion in a patient not eligible for further systemic therapy.
Procedure details: Ultrasound confirmed a large left effusion. Trocar entry at the 6th intercostal space allowed drainage of 1.5 L of serous fluid. Thoracoscopy showed nodular parietal pleura; no diaphragmatic defects. Biopsies were obtained. Talc slurry (4 g in 50 mL saline) was instilled evenly. A 24 Fr chest tube was placed.
Complications: None.
Estimated blood loss: 30 mL.
Disposition: Admitted overnight to thoracic ward.
Plan: Monitor chest tube output; palliative care support; outpatient follow-up in 1–2 weeks.

registry_entry.primary_indication: New contralateral malignant pleural effusion in mesothelioma
registry_entry.radiographic_findings: Large left pleural effusion with compressive atelectasis; prior right talc pleurodesis changes
registry_entry.prior_therapy: Right-sided talc pleurodesis; prior systemic chemotherapy
registry_entry.pleural_thoracoscopy_findings: Diffuse nodular pleural involvement consistent with mesothelioma
registry_entry.final_diagnosis_prelim: Malignant pleural effusion from mesothelioma with successful contralateral talc pleurodesis
registry_entry.follow_up_plan: Palliative care and thoracic surgery follow-up; chest tube removal when drainage low

note_text:
Interventional Pulmonology Procedure Note
Procedure: Medical thoracoscopy with talc pleurodesis for malignant pleural effusion in lung adenocarcinoma (bilateral disease, unilateral treatment).
Patient: Ava Thompson, 67-year-old female with metastatic lung adenocarcinoma and bilateral pleural effusions, left greater than right.
Anesthesia: Moderate sedation with midazolam and fentanyl; supplemental oxygen via nasal cannula.
Indication: Symptomatic left-dominant malignant pleural effusion causing orthopnea.
Procedure details: Ultrasound-guided entry at the left 7th intercostal space allowed drainage of 1.7 L serosanguinous fluid. Thoracoscopy revealed diffuse parietal pleural implants. Biopsies were obtained. Talc slurry (4 g in 50 mL saline) was instilled and distributed. A 20 Fr chest tube was secured.
Complications: None.
Estimated blood loss: 25 mL.
Disposition: Admitted to oncology floor.
Plan: Monitor drainage and respiratory status; consider right-sided tunneled pleural catheter if contralateral effusion becomes symptomatic.

registry_entry.pleural_thoracoscopy_findings: Diffuse parietal pleural implants with scattered diaphragmatic involvement

note_text:
Interventional Pulmonology Procedure Note
Procedure: Medical thoracoscopy with pleural biopsies for undiagnosed exudative pleural effusion.
Patient: Grace Wilson, 58-year-old female with persistent left exudative pleural effusion of unclear etiology.
Anesthesia: Moderate sedation with midazolam and fentanyl; local lidocaine at port site.
Indication: Recurrent left exudative pleural effusion with negative cytology on two prior thoracenteses; concern for malignancy versus tuberculosis.
Procedure details: Ultrasound guidance identified a moderate free-flowing left pleural effusion. A single-port semi-rigid thoracoscope was introduced at the 6th intercostal space. Approximately 1.1 L of cloudy, straw-colored fluid was drained. Thoracoscopic inspection revealed diffuse granular parietal pleural thickening with scattered small nodules and fibrin strands. Multiple biopsies (10 samples) were taken from abnormal parietal pleura and diaphragmatic pleura. No chemical or mechanical pleurodesis was performed. A 20 Fr chest tube was placed to water seal.
Complications: None.
Estimated blood loss: 20 mL.
Disposition: Admitted overnight for observation and chest tube management.
Plan: Send pleural fluid and tissue for cytology, AFB smear/culture, fungal culture, and histopathology; chest tube removal when drainage low and no air leak; follow-up in IP clinic in 1 week.

registry_entry.primary_indication: Undiagnosed recurrent left exudative pleural effusion suspicious for malignancy or TB
registry_entry.radiographic_findings: Moderate left pleural effusion with pleural thickening on CT
registry_entry.prior_therapy: Two diagnostic/therapeutic thoracenteses with negative cytology
registry_entry.pleural_thoracoscopy_findings: Diffuse granular pleural thickening and small nodules without obvious bulky tumor
registry_entry.bronch_specimen_tests: Pleural biopsies for histology, AFB, fungal stains and cultures
registry_entry.final_diagnosis_prelim: Undiagnosed exudative pleural effusion; pleural biopsies pending
registry_entry.follow_up_plan: Await histopathology and microbiology; IP clinic follow-up in 7–10 days

note_text:
Interventional Pulmonology Procedure Note
Procedure: Medical thoracoscopy with pleural biopsies for suspected pleural mesothelioma.
Patient: Ryan Brooks, 69-year-old male with occupational asbestos exposure and right pleural thickening with effusion.
Anesthesia: General anesthesia with single-lumen ETT.
Indication: Progressive right pleural thickening and moderate effusion seen on CT; need tissue diagnosis.
Procedure details: Right 5th intercostal space, midaxillary line, was chosen under ultrasound. After trocar placement, 900 mL of serous fluid was drained. Thoracoscopy revealed diffuse nodular and plaque-like thickening of the parietal pleura, especially over the diaphragmatic and posterior chest wall. Multiple large biopsies (12 samples) were obtained with rigid forceps from representative areas. No pleurodesis was performed due to diagnostic intent and uncertain staging plan. A 24 Fr chest tube was placed to water seal.
Complications: Mild oozing at biopsy sites controlled with cautery and topical epinephrine.
Estimated blood loss: 50 mL.
Disposition: Admitted to thoracic surgery floor.
Plan: Send specimens for histology and BAP1/MTAP staining; PET/CT and multidisciplinary tumor board discussion after diagnosis.

registry_entry.primary_indication: Suspected malignant pleural mesothelioma with right pleural thickening and effusion
registry_entry.radiographic_findings: Circumferential right pleural thickening with moderate effusion on CT
registry_entry.prior_therapy: None beyond diagnostic thoracentesis
registry_entry.pleural_thoracoscopy_findings: Diffuse nodular parietal pleural thickening concerning for mesothelioma
registry_entry.bronch_specimen_tests: Pleural biopsies for histology, immunohistochemistry including BAP1/MTAP
registry_entry.bronch_immediate_complications: Mild oozing controlled with cautery and topical epinephrine
registry_entry.final_diagnosis_prelim: Pleural nodularity highly suspicious for mesothelioma; final pathology pending
registry_entry.follow_up_plan: Obtain PET/CT after histologic confirmation; tumor board discussion within 2 weeks

cpt_codes.description: Thoracoscopy, surgical; with biopsy of pleura

note_text:
Interventional Pulmonology Procedure Note
Procedure: Medical thoracoscopy with pleural biopsies for suspected rheumatoid pleuritis.
Patient: Isabella Martinez, 54-year-old female with longstanding seropositive rheumatoid arthritis and recurrent right exudative pleural effusion.
Anesthesia: Moderate sedation with midazolam and fentanyl.
Indication: Recurrent right pleural effusion with low pleural glucose and high LDH; need tissue diagnosis to distinguish rheumatoid pleuritis from malignancy.
Procedure details: Ultrasound confirmed a moderate right effusion without loculations. A semi-rigid thoracoscope was introduced at the 6th intercostal space. 900 mL of cloudy, yellow fluid was removed. Parietal pleura appeared diffusely inflamed with small whitish nodules; no bulky tumor. Multiple biopsies (8 samples) were obtained from parietal and diaphragmatic pleura. No pleurodesis performed. A 16 Fr chest tube was left in place.
Complications: None.
Estimated blood loss: 10 mL.
Disposition: Observed overnight on rheumatology ward.
Plan: Send pleural tissue for histology and microbiology; adjust RA therapy pending results.

registry_entry.primary_indication: Recurrent right exudative pleural effusion in rheumatoid arthritis with low pleural glucose
registry_entry.radiographic_findings: Moderate right pleural effusion; no discrete lung mass
registry_entry.prior_therapy: RA disease-modifying therapy; prior diagnostic thoracentesis
registry_entry.pleural_thoracoscopy_findings: Diffuse erythematous pleura with fine whitish nodules; no obvious malignancy
registry_entry.bronch_specimen_tests: Pleural biopsies for histology and culture
registry_entry.final_diagnosis_prelim: Exudative pleural effusion likely secondary to rheumatoid pleuritis; pathology pending
registry_entry.follow_up_plan: Rheumatology follow-up; adjust disease-modifying therapy after biopsy results

note_text:
Interventional Pulmonology Procedure Note
Procedure: Medical thoracoscopy with pleural biopsies for suspected tuberculous pleuritis.
Patient: Ahmed Ali, 46-year-old male with recent travel to high TB-prevalence region and unilateral left pleural effusion.
Anesthesia: Moderate sedation with midazolam and fentanyl.
Indication: Subacute fever, weight loss, and left exudative lymphocyte-predominant pleural effusion with elevated ADA level; need diagnostic confirmation.
Procedure details: Ultrasound-demonstrated moderate left pleural effusion. A single-port thoracoscope was introduced at the 5th intercostal space. 800 mL of straw-colored fluid was drained. Parietal pleura displayed diffuse whitish nodules and fibrinous adhesions. Multiple biopsies were obtained from costal and diaphragmatic pleura. No pleurodesis was performed. A 16 Fr chest tube was placed under water seal.
Complications: None.
Estimated blood loss: 15 mL.
Disposition: Admitted to infectious diseases ward.
Plan: Send pleural tissue for histology, AFB smear and culture, Xpert MTB/RIF, and mycobacterial PCR; initiate empiric anti-tuberculous therapy if pathology supportive.

registry_entry.institution_name: Synthetic Infectious Disease and Lung Center
registry_entry.primary_indication: Suspected tuberculous pleuritis with unilateral effusion and high ADA
registry_entry.radiographic_findings: Moderate left pleural effusion with adjacent pleural thickening
registry_entry.prior_therapy: Diagnostic thoracentesis with high ADA and lymphocytic exudate
registry_entry.pleural_thoracoscopy_findings: Diffuse small whitish nodules and fibrinous adhesions consistent with TB pleuritis
registry_entry.bronch_specimen_tests: Pleural biopsies for histology, AFB smear/culture, PCR
registry_entry.final_diagnosis_prelim: Findings suggestive of tuberculous pleuritis; confirmatory microbiology pending
registry_entry.follow_up_plan: Start empiric TB therapy if pathology consistent; infectious diseases follow-up

note_text:
Interventional Pulmonology Procedure Note
Procedure: Medical thoracoscopy with pleural biopsies for suspected pleural carcinomatosis from gastric cancer.
Patient: Mei Chen, 62-year-old female with metastatic gastric adenocarcinoma and new right pleural effusion.
Anesthesia: General anesthesia with single-lumen ETT.
Indication: Progressive dyspnea and right pleural effusion with equivocal cytology; need definitive pleural tissue diagnosis to guide therapy.
Procedure details: A semi-rigid thoracoscope was introduced via the right 6th intercostal space. 1.0 L of serous fluid was drained. Multiple small nodules and plaques were seen over the diaphragmatic and basal parietal pleura. Representative biopsies (10 samples) were obtained. No pleurodesis was performed due to uncertainty about future systemic therapy plan and potential need for intraperitoneal chemotherapy. A 20 Fr chest tube was placed.
Complications: None.
Estimated blood loss: 25 mL.
Disposition: Admitted to oncology ward.
Plan: Send biopsies for histology and HER2 testing; tumor board discussion after pathology available.

registry_entry.primary_indication: Right pleural effusion in metastatic gastric adenocarcinoma with equivocal cytology
registry_entry.radiographic_findings: Moderate right pleural effusion without dominant lung mass; known peritoneal carcinomatosis
registry_entry.prior_therapy: Systemic chemotherapy for gastric adenocarcinoma
registry_entry.pleural_thoracoscopy_findings: Multiple small nodules and plaques over diaphragmatic and basal parietal pleura

note_text:
Interventional Pulmonology Procedure Note
Procedure: Medical thoracoscopy with pleural biopsies for suspected drug-induced pleuritis.
Patient: Zoe Ramirez, 39-year-old female with recent initiation of amiodarone therapy and new bilateral pleural effusions, right greater than left.
Anesthesia: Moderate sedation with midazolam and fentanyl.
Indication: Right-predominant exudative pleural effusion with eosinophilia; need pleural tissue to distinguish drug toxicity from autoimmune or malignant causes.
Procedure details: Ultrasound demonstrated a moderate right effusion. A semi-rigid thoracoscope was advanced via the 6th intercostal space. 700 mL of serous fluid was removed. Parietal pleura appeared mildly thickened with scattered petechial hemorrhages but no distinct nodules. Multiple biopsies (6 samples) were obtained. No pleurodesis was performed. A 16 Fr chest tube was left in situ.
Complications: None.
Estimated blood loss: 10 mL.
Disposition: Observed overnight.
Plan: Send pleural tissue for histology and immunofluorescence; cardiology to consider discontinuing amiodarone depending on results.

registry_entry.primary_indication: Right-predominant exudative pleural effusion with eosinophilia after amiodarone initiation
registry_entry.radiographic_findings: Bilateral pleural effusions, larger on the right, without lung mass
registry_entry.prior_therapy: Therapeutic thoracentesis with eosinophilic exudate
registry_entry.pleural_thoracoscopy_findings: Mild pleural thickening and petechial hemorrhages without focal nodules
registry_entry.bronch_specimen_tests: Pleural biopsies for histology and immunofluorescence
registry_entry.final_diagnosis_prelim: Suspected drug-induced pleuritis; definitive diagnosis pending histology
registry_entry.follow_up_plan: Cardiology and pulmonology follow-up; adjust antiarrhythmic regimen based on biopsy

note_text:
Interventional Pulmonology Procedure Note
Procedure: Medical thoracoscopy with pleural biopsies for suspected malignant pleural effusion in lymphoma.
Patient: Connor Davis, 48-year-old male with diffuse large B-cell lymphoma and new left pleural effusion.
Anesthesia: General anesthesia with single-lumen ETT.
Indication: New unilateral pleural effusion in a patient with lymphoma; need pleural tissue to differentiate reactive effusion from direct pleural involvement.
Procedure details: Left 6th intercostal space was accessed under ultrasound guidance. 1.2 L of serous fluid was evacuated. Parietal pleura appeared mildly thickened with scattered pale nodules. Multiple biopsies (10 samples) were taken and submitted for histology, flow cytometry, and cytogenetics. No pleurodesis was performed. A 20 Fr chest tube was positioned posteriorly.
Complications: None.
Estimated blood loss: 20 mL.
Disposition: Admitted to hematology ward.
Plan: Await pathology and flow cytometry; adjust lymphoma regimen as indicated.

registry_entry.primary_indication: Left pleural effusion in patient with diffuse large B-cell lymphoma
registry_entry.radiographic_findings: Moderate left pleural effusion; mediastinal lymphadenopathy
registry_entry.prior_therapy: Systemic chemotherapy for lymphoma
registry_entry.pleural_thoracoscopy_findings: Mildly thickened parietal pleura with scattered small nodules
registry_entry.bronch_specimen_tests: Pleural biopsies for histology, flow cytometry, and cytogenetics
registry_entry.final_diagnosis_prelim: Pleural thickening suspicious for lymphoma involvement; final pathology pending
registry_entry.follow_up_plan: Hematology follow-up; adjust chemotherapy regimen based on pleural involvement

note_text:
Interventional Pulmonology Procedure Note
Procedure: Medical thoracoscopy with pleural biopsies for unilateral transudative-appearing effusion in heart failure.
Patient: William Scott, 74-year-old male with heart failure with reduced ejection fraction and large right pleural effusion that appears transudative by Light’s criteria but has atypical cytology.
Anesthesia: Moderate sedation with midazolam and fentanyl.
Indication: Atypical cells noted on pleural cytology in otherwise transudative-appearing effusion; need pleural biopsy to exclude malignancy.
Procedure details: Ultrasound-guided entry at the right 7th intercostal space. 1.5 L of clear, straw-colored fluid was drained. Thoracoscopy revealed smooth glistening pleura without nodules. Multiple random biopsies (6 samples) of parietal pleura were obtained. No pleurodesis performed. A 20 Fr chest tube was left in place on water seal.
Complications: None.
Estimated blood loss: 15 mL.
Disposition: Admitted to cardiology floor.
Plan: Await pathology; adjust diuretic therapy for heart failure; consider repeat cytology if effusion recurs.

registry_entry.primary_indication: Large right pleural effusion in heart failure with atypical cytology
registry_entry.radiographic_findings: Large right pleural effusion with cardiomegaly
registry_entry.prior_therapy: Aggressive diuresis with persistent effusion; diagnostic thoracentesis
registry_entry.pleural_thoracoscopy_findings: Smooth pleura without nodules or plaques
registry_entry.bronch_specimen_tests: Random pleural biopsies for histology and cytology correlation
registry_entry.final_diagnosis_prelim: Pleural surfaces grossly benign; pathology pending to exclude malignancy
registry_entry.follow_up_plan: Cardiology follow-up; repeat imaging to assess recurrence; consider pleurodesis only if malignant and recurrent

note_text:
Interventional Pulmonology Procedure Note
Procedure: Medical thoracoscopy with pleural biopsies for suspected pleural sarcoidosis.
Patient: Natalie Perez, 44-year-old female with pulmonary sarcoidosis and new right exudative pleural effusion.
Anesthesia: Moderate sedation with midazolam and fentanyl.
Indication: Persistent right pleural effusion in patient with sarcoidosis; need pleural histology to distinguish sarcoid pleuritis from malignancy.
Procedure details: Ultrasound demonstrated a small-to-moderate right free-flowing effusion. A semi-rigid thoracoscope was introduced at the 5th intercostal space. 600 mL of clear, yellow exudate was drained. Parietal pleura showed fine nodularity along the ribs. Multiple biopsies (8 samples) were obtained. No pleurodesis was done. A 16 Fr chest tube was left to drain.
Complications: None.
Estimated blood loss: 10 mL.
Disposition: Observed overnight on pulmonary ward.
Plan: Send pleural tissue for histology and special stains; adjust sarcoidosis therapy pending results.

registry_entry.primary_indication: Right exudative pleural effusion in sarcoidosis
registry_entry.radiographic_findings: Right pleural effusion with upper-lobe predominant parenchymal changes consistent with sarcoidosis
registry_entry.prior_therapy: Systemic steroids for pulmonary sarcoidosis
registry_entry.pleural_thoracoscopy_findings: Fine nodularity of the parietal pleura suggestive of granulomatous disease
registry_entry.bronch_specimen_tests: Pleural biopsies for histology and special stains for granulomatous inflammation
registry_entry.final_diagnosis_prelim: Pleural nodularity likely due to sarcoidosis; histologic confirmation pending
registry_entry.follow_up_plan: Pulmonology follow-up; adjust steroid or immunosuppressive regimen after pathology

note_text:
Interventional Pulmonology Procedure Note
Procedure: Medical thoracoscopy with pleural biopsies for suspected pleural metastases from colorectal cancer.
Patient: Jason Wright, 63-year-old male with metastatic colorectal adenocarcinoma and new left pleural effusion.
Anesthesia: General anesthesia with single-lumen ETT.
Indication: New symptomatic unilateral pleural effusion in metastatic colorectal cancer; need pleural histology to guide prognosis and treatment.
Procedure details: Ultrasound-guided access at the left 6th intercostal space allowed insertion of a semi-rigid thoracoscope. 1.0 L of straw-colored fluid was drained. Parietal pleura showed scattered small nodules and subtle plaques. Multiple biopsies (8 samples) were taken. No pleurodesis performed because systemic therapy options are being reconsidered. A 20 Fr chest tube was placed.
Complications: None.
Estimated blood loss: 20 mL.
Disposition: Admitted overnight on oncology ward.
Plan: Pleural biopsies for histology and KRAS/NRAS status if malignant; discuss at tumor board for treatment planning.

registry_entry.primary_indication: New left pleural effusion in metastatic colorectal carcinoma
registry_entry.radiographic_findings: Moderate left pleural effusion; liver metastases present
registry_entry.prior_therapy: Multiple lines of systemic chemotherapy for colorectal cancer
registry_entry.pleural_thoracoscopy_findings: Scattered small nodules and plaques over parietal pleura
registry_entry.bronch_specimen_tests: Pleural biopsies for histology and molecular testing if malignant
registry_entry.final_diagnosis_prelim: Pleural metastases suspected; pathology pending
registry_entry.follow_up_plan: Tumor board review; adjust systemic regimen depending on pleural involvement and molecular testing
